note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

Madison McAfee was a political figure in Mississippi, who ran for governor in 1861 and served as the state’s quartermaster general during the Civil War.

Born in Lawrence, Mississippi in 1818, McAfee served a public auditor in Mississippi during the late 1850s. Shortly after Mississippi declared its secession from the Union in early 1861, McAfee received an appointment as quartermaster general for the state’s military. As part of the “Military Board” overseeing the Mississippi militia, McAfee clashed with Governor John J. Pettus. He ran for governor as a moderate Democrat against Pettus in a contentious election in the fall of 1861. However, in September, before the election, McAfee stepped away from the gubernatorial race, reportedly citing his desire to avoid a highly partisan political battle in the midst of the war. McAfee died the following year, 1862.

(The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, July 20, 1859; The American Citizen, Canton, MS, September 21, 1861; Robert W. Dubay, “Mississippi,” The Confederate Governors, ed. W. Buck Yearns, 118-119; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 31, 148, 424)

The first newspaper published in Mississippi was the Mississippi Gazette, which went into print around 1800 in Natchez, before Mississippi Territory was formally organized. Several more appeared during the next few years, and by the time Mississippi entered the Union in 1817 at least half a dozen different publications had emerged. Over the following years, newspaper companies opened as communities grew and the demand for information increased. Publishing resources (like paper and print presses) became more available aiding in the news media boom. By the mid-nineteenth century, most Mississippi towns or counties had a local newspaper, published daily or weekly. Major cities typically had more than one newspaper, often published by competing political parties. Most newspapers went out of business after only a few years; however, a few continued in print for decades, including The Columbus Democrat in Columbus (1836–1877), The Kosciusko Chronicle in Kosciusko (1846–1892), and the Grenada Sentinel of Grenada which started in 1868 and remained in publication until 1955. Overall, as many as two hundred different publishers started daily or weekly newspapers in Mississippi during the nineteenth century. (Tim Hughes, “The first newspapers in Mississippi…,” History’s Newsstand Blog; Library of Congress)

Located in Paulding, Mississippi, the Eastern Clarion was a newspaper business established in 1837 and operating until 1863 when its name was changed to the Weekly Clarion and it was moved to Meridian, Mississippi, where it continued publication until 1882. (Chronicling America)
Located in Jackson, Mississippi, The Weekly Mississippian was a weekly newspaper company operating from 1859 until 1864. (Library of Congress)

Impoverished people are those who lack "a usual or socially acceptable amount of money or material possessions," or alternately those who "lack the means to satisfy their basic needs (Britannica). This definition, necessarily subjective and broad, indicates that what one person or society deems "socially acceptable" or what constitutes "basic needs" is malleable.

Similarly, impoverished people in the United States in the nineteenth century did not fit one specific category. The rise of industrialism produced an increased number of impoverished people in the U. S., particularly within large urban centers. European immigrants in cities in the East, and Chinese immigrants on the West Coast, and African Americans in the South were disproportionately affected by poverty. Regionally, the highest number of impoverished people came from the U. S. South, where "both whites and African Americans struggled with debt, low cotton prices, laws favorable to employers and creditors, paltry alternatives, and the general post war devastation" (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 2, 547).

Racism and nativism among employers and employees also made economic advancement more difficult for people of color and immigrants. However, the impoverished made up a comparatively low percentage of Mississippi's antebellum population, given its low number of immigrants and even native residents, lack of industrialization and urbanization, and mobility of those that were impoverished (Mississippi Encyclopedia). Many reform organizations throughout the country took the lead in fighting poverty in the nineteenth century, while state and federal governments by the end of the century also developed its own institutional responses. The status of being impoverished has always carried negative connotations in American history, so CWRGM uses the tag "Impoverished people" to emphasize the personhood of those in poverty rather than their social status.

div.p: There is but little wool in the country, mostly used up & no money among the people to buy with, if we had wool the people not only willing but very anxious to work & any amount of good substantial clotheing would be speedily made, the most of families in this neighborhood have & are haveing made looms

is there no way that you could furnish wool to the people 100ts in this neighborhood would offer a very great facility to making of the necessary clotheing in fact I do not see how we are to get along without some relief in this way the Pearl River factory at Jackson have plenty of wool rolls & spun yarn for socks

I think General McAfee is on the wrong track this pass, he is a patriotic clever popular gentleman, but unless I mistake the signs of the times he will be wonderfully mistaken. I have been but little among the people, yet I feel well assured that you will get a very large majority in this county. I saw in the Eastern Clarion your answer to inquirer, I think you gave him a quietus. I was truly gratified in reading your clear

satisfactory & I think convincing exposition. this was much needed, the people for the want of proper information, was a little restive. I shall probably mix a little with the people & I shall feel it a duty to make known your answer to inquirer &c, as well as a pleasure
I take the weekly Mississippia, if your answer to inquirer was published in the weekly, it has escaped my attention
